climbs.name: West wall route
climbs.fa: unknown  -one of the first in the canyon

content.description: on the west face near the highway corner of the crag,  three bolts lead up to a shallow right leaning corner/dihedral which is followed to the upper tier ledge and a small pine to belay from.  The crus is just after third bolt, and some SMALL tcus are needed to protect the right leaning corner- where one or two placements can be found
content.protection: 3 draws and a couple of small tcus, sling for tree belay

content.description: a short corner just left of "freezer-box"  Climb an obvious small corner past a few bushes to the belay ledge of freezer box
two flared cracks just left of the west wall- both can be top roped and are equal in difficulty- spaced a few feet apart from each other.

a striking short crack on the south face- starts on the upper tier, and is very short but strenuous off hands in a parallel yosemite like crack, which leads to a small easy arch and finish.  Could be bouldered, but there have been injuries from coming off, and slipping off the entire upper tier..
content.location: south face, upper tier of apron on the left side

content.description: On the left side of the west face of the Apron near low angle slabs is a dirty slot that leads up passing a bulge at 100', then a little higher to 4th class ledges and a walk off to the north.
content.location: left side of west face- Apron crag

content.description: off width chimney on the south face of the apron.  Cracks inside help protect the chimnet to an exit out the top onto a fifteen foot slab(5.7) to a belay ledge.

5.7 to the overhang section. The whole overhanging crack is flared locks and pumpy thin hands. Get psyched it's ferocious! The Crack does expand with temperature, a little thinner when cold and a little wider when hot so your hand size will dictate what's better. Still hard no matter what.
content.protection: .3 to #1 BD. optional #4 for the 5.7 start.
content.location: See"dont let me down" directions, obvious overhanging splitter just right of a bolt ladder.

content.description: just right of an old unfinished bolt ladder on the south face of the apron is the overhanging dihederal and crack.  5.6 up to the crack, which is nailed via a3 expando nailing to a 5.7 mantle off of it to the left near the top which is awkward!  Beware of the EXPANDO nature of the HUGE block!

the striking and obvious flake on the right edge of the upper tier -south face of the Apron.  Jamming, liebacks and under clings on a difficult to protect route!   Ive recenty named this "unkown" route in honor of Peter Haans yosemite wheat thin, as i think thuis route could actually use the same tactic to preserve the flake.
